","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-05-09T04:19:35.201Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":539,"readers_count":538,"score":142.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501434,"topic_slug":"frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release","display_username":"Anthony Ung","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66446,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Student - pulsefrc.app"},"post_url":"/t/frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release/501434/3","custom_user_title":"Design Student - pulsefrc.app","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3617838,"name":"Anthony Ung","username":"aung","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aung/{size}/239119_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-09T04:33:36.898Z","cooked":"

In the development of the coaxially driven robotic shoulder joint, how was the specific gear ratio designated to help optimize the torque requirements with the movement velocity of the coaxially driven robotic shoulder joint, particularly under applications where speed and precision are paramount (i.e., arm pivots, elevators, and wrist joints)? Additionally, what nuanced trade-offs were there to consider concerning factors like control precision and system responsiveness within the framework of the coaxially driven robotic shoulder joint?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-05-09T04:33:36.898Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":521,"readers_count":520,"score":124.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":501434,"topic_slug":"frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release","display_username":"Anthony Ung","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66446,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Student - pulsefrc.app"},"post_url":"/t/frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release/501434/4","custom_user_title":"Design Student - pulsefrc.app","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3617840,"name":"Eric Zeng","username":"UltimateNoob","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ultimatenoob/{size}/232810_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-09T04:41:20.567Z","cooked":"

When designing the coaxially driven floor intake, what nuanced considerations were made when selecting the most optimal material for the intake rollers on the coaxially driven floor intake to ensure sufficient rigidity for withstanding collisions to the coaxially driven floor intake? Additionally, how was the most optimal durometer of each wheel on the coaxially driven floor intake determined? Regarding the indexing system which the coaxially driven floor intake fed into, were there any challenges encountered in powering it with a single motor, as opposed to the dual-motor setup used by teams like 2056 and 1690?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-05-09T04:44:05.900Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":478,"readers_count":477,"score":115.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501434,"topic_slug":"frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release","display_username":"Eric Zeng","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66452,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9659A"},"post_url":"/t/frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release/501434/5","custom_user_title":"9659A","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3617884,"name":"Matthew S.","username":"Matthaeus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/matthaeus/{size}/256805_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-09T09:42:03.075Z","cooked":"

When it came to deciding on the final drive ratio for the arm, we utilized ReCalc and hand calculations to minimize time to position on our arm. When looking at the tradeoffs for a coaxial setup, ultimately the reduction of failure modes on our extension into the reef where our arm is vulnerable drove those decisions. The biggest hurdle for the coaxial setup was simply the final belt stage that helped in reducing backlash in the arm as a whole with our front tensioner block.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-05-09T09:42:03.075Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":432,"readers_count":431,"score":86.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":501434,"topic_slug":"frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release","display_username":"Matthew S.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":66446,"username":"aung","name":"Anthony Ung","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aung/{size}/239119_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54928,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2046 | CAD Glazer | President "},"post_url":"/t/frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release/501434/6","custom_user_title":"2046 | CAD Glazer | President ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3617885,"name":"Matthew S.","username":"Matthaeus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/matthaeus/{size}/256805_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-09T09:44:47.266Z","cooked":"

We derived alot of inspiration when it came to our dead-axle stubbed roller design from our 2024 season to beefen up our intake to impacts. As for intake geometry, through alot of prototyping throughout the entire build season, we arrived at our intake design simplifying our indexer to a single motor and using a slam-down style intake.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-05-09T12:59:43.306Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":361,"readers_count":360,"score":102.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":501434,"topic_slug":"frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release","display_username":"James Lyon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71354,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8410 Mechanical Lead "},"post_url":"/t/frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release/501434/11","custom_user_title":"8410 Mechanical Lead ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3619070,"name":"Anthony Ung","username":"aung","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aung/{size}/239119_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-10T17:24:27.645Z","cooked":"

When developing the initial architecture for the robotic pipe scoring machine, what strategic decision-making processes did your team go through when selecting an modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve system for your drive base, did your game analysis indicate that a modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve system was needed to play the game at the level your team wanted to? Were there any nuanced trade offs to take into account and consider when making the decision to go with a modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve system? Additionally, why did you decide to use your particular brand (swerve drive specialties) of modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve modules? Were there any advantages compared to other commercial off the shelf modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve solutions on the market? Or was your brand of modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve systems chosen due to past familiarity and known robustness/reliability during competition? Also, what was the thought process behind the particular configuration of modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve system modules, according to the technical details in your technical tech binder, you have three swerve drive specialties inverted modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve system modules, and one inverted narrow configuration of the swerve drive specialties modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve system module. What was the strategy and decision making process behind this choice?

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-05-10T17:24:27.645Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":328,"readers_count":327,"score":115.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501434,"topic_slug":"frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release","display_username":"Anthony Ung","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66446,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Student - pulsefrc.app"},"post_url":"/t/frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release/501434/12","custom_user_title":"Design Student - pulsefrc.app","reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3619108,"name":"Nolan Evans","username":"NolanE995","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nolane995/{size}/261487_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-10T18:32:12.121Z","cooked":"

According to the technical documentation, the team opted to integrate a single Swerve Drive Specialties MK4i Narrow module in an inverted configuration to provide additional spatial clearance for their vertical linear actuation system.

Swerve module selection is inherently application-specific—each COTS vendor (e.g., REV Robotics MAXSwerve, West Coast Products X-series, Swerve Drive Specialties MK4/MK4i) offers distinct mechanical and performance tradeoffs including packaging geometry, bearing stackup, azimuth motor integration, and wheel accessibility.

Ultimately, optimal module selection is contingent on drivetrain footprint, subsystem interfacing constraints, maintenance requirements, and team fabrication capabilities. For instance, my team previously deployed the WCP Swerve Xi modules in the 2024 season and are transitioning to the X2i model for 2025, appreciating improvements in weight distribution, encoder accessibility, and integrated bevel gear support.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-05-10T18:32:12.121Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":110.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":501434,"topic_slug":"frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release","display_username":"Nolan Evans","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":66446,"username":"aung","name":"Anthony Ung","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aung/{size}/239119_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75491,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/frc-bear-metal-2046-2025-robot-cad-release/501434/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3619219,"name":"Isaac S","username":"MearBetal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mearbetal/{size}/252620_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-10T21:48:54.009Z","cooked":"

Last year, we had a lengthy discussion covering the pros and cons of each COTs swerve module. I don’t remember all the exact points (will follow up post ap-exams with reasoning). But this year, we stuck with SDS due to familiarity, not having to spend more to buy a full new set of swerves and the ability to run a MK4n, which as Nolan brought up, gave us the spacing to put our elevator between swerves and stay at 26.5 by 26.5. In hindsight however, expanding to ~28” was probably the right decision, just for the extra stability, even with the additional weight reduction it would require.
